channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #53 - Is it reasonable to write new code in Perl right now?
item.description:
Hi,

It seems there were fewer posts this week than usual but OTOH it seems there are slightly more Perl 6 related posts. Of course I might be biased a bit, as recently I started to pay attention to Perl 6 again. Even writing articles.

I also released the first sellable edition of the Advanced Perl Maven book. (see below). I am planning to publish another two e-books in the near future and then I think I am going to focus just on writing articles. Please bear with me. (I had to look that up, and there were some funny explanations on the differences between 'bear with me' and 'bare with me' :). See also 'beer with me'.

Back to the title story. Actually I think the usage of Perl won't grow much as long as our conversation can be described by that title. We need to change that question to:

'Is Perl the best choice for this project?'

What do you think? Please reply to this e-mail telling me what do you think!

Enjoy (and share!) the articles:

item.title: Announcing Catalyst Community Poll and Upcoming Town Hall
item.description: John Napiorkowski has published a 10-minute long survey about the Catalyst web framework. (It is less than 20 questions.) I don't see a dead-line so, I'd recommend you head over and fill it out ASAP, before it is closed.

item.title: Announcing the Advanced Perl Maven e-book
item.description: This is my second e-book. Based on the training material I am using and already including a few articles. Currently selling at 30% of its final price. It also includes a challenge to find your way how to buy it. If you get lost, let me know by e-mail, I'll help you through.

item.title: Manage your web app with commands
item.description: Glen Hinkle tempi.re describes how to add commands to a Mojolicious application.

item.title: Partial parsing and error reporting using Marpa
Perl bits: Passing @_ to a subroutine
item.description: Do you know what does &foo do? Asked and answered by Sebastian Willing

item.title: Some lessons in optimizing Org::Parser
item.description: What do you do if your notebook is small and slow? Steven Haryanto had to profile his perl scripts to make them run at a reasonable speed. I liked the way the story is told.

item.title: The Lost Secret of Mug-Driven Evolution
item.description: chromatic raised the question 'Is it reasonable to write new code in Perl right now?' and has discussed it a bit, thought the main point - something you might have heard earlier - is in the closing sentence: 'Build credible new things. Brag about them. Repeat.'. The comments section also contained a fair amount of good comments. For example the explanataion of Ovid about the Osborne effect.

item.title: Is it reasonable to write new code in Perl right now?
item.description: Su-Shee took the question asked by chromatic and had a longish response why she, after checking out Java, Ruby and Python, thinks Perl is still the best choice for her company.

item.title: List of Perl modules comparison articles
item.description: In recent years there were several articles comparing modules for specific task. Steven Haryanto created a wiki page with the hope of linking to all such comparison articles.

item.title: Alien::Base Perl Foundation Grant Report Month 5
item.description: Joel Berger had made some progress on the Mac front and uploaded a few modules to CPAN to be test cases for Alien::Base.

item.title: Improving Perl 5: Grant Report for Month 10
item.description: Nicholas Clark writes about the investigation and fix of a potential security issue in all versions of perl 5. He also explains why this is probably did not add any extra vulnerability to code pointing out other security issues a programmer could introduce by using unverified user data.

item.title: How does interpolation of scalars, arrays and hashes work in Perl 6
item.description: On one hand Perl 6 only interpolates scalars and not arrays, on the other hand Perl 6 has a clean syntax to interpolate the results of any expression.

item.title: Making an IF game in August
item.description: If you were worried what will you do after Carl Masak finishes his month of blogging, don't worry. The Rakudo Death Star announcd its plan to make a game in August.

item.title: Rakudo Star 2012.07 released
item.description: As usual, this includes both the Rakudo compiler, the Parrot Virtual Machine, a bunch of extra modules and documentation. In an announcement from today you can also learn about the binary distribution of Rakudo Start for Windows.

item.title: Rakudo QAST switch brings memory reductions
item.description: One of the issues I found when building Rakudo on a small virtual box was that it ran out of memory. (OK, I had only 512 Mb allocated. I had to add 1 Gb swap space to get compilation finish.) This change makes it much more likely that you'll be able to compile Rakudo even on machine with little memory.

item.title: Building and adventure game in Perl 6
item.description: Carl Masak almost finished his month of blogging. Check out the TOC with the links to all the posts.

item.title: Security vulnerabilities in three commonly deployed RT extensions
MetaCPAN favourites weekly report
Perl 5 Porters Weekly: July 16-July 22, 2012
item.description: Perl 5.17.2 is now available; Finally there is work being done for Perl on Android!

item.title: Stackoverflow Perl report
How to change @INC to find Perl modules in non-standard locations
item.description: How can you use a module without installing it? Is a frequent question. In this article I gave 3 solutions for 3 different use-cases.

item.title: YAPC::EU 2012
item.description: August 20-22, 2012, Frankfurt, Germany

item.title: Moving to Moose Hackathon
item.description: August 25-30, Preikestolen Mountain Lodge, near Stavanger, Norway

item.title: YAPC::Asia Tokyo 2012
item.description: September 27-29, 2012, Tokyo, Japan

item.title: Italian Perl workshop
item.description: October 11-12, 2012, Bologna, Italy
